title: R44693
content: The FMLA requires covered employers to grant up to 12 workweeks of leave for various reasons, including the birth or adoption of a child, caring for a family member with a serious health condition, the employee's own health condition, and military exigencies. Additionally, eligible employees can receive up to 26 workweeks of leave to care for a covered military servicemember with a serious injury or illness. Employees must meet certain criteria to be eligible for FMLA leave. The FMLA provides up to 12 workweeks of leave for various reasons, including caring for a family member with a serious health condition or military exigencies. Eligibility criteria include working for a covered employer with 1,250 hours of service in the past 12 months and 50 employees within 75 miles of the worksite. Public agencies are covered employers regardless of staffing levels, but public-sector employees must meet the worksite coverage requirement. Amendments have expanded coverage to legislative branch employees and created military family leave entitlements. The FMLA has been amended multiple times since 1993 to cover legislative branch employees, create military family leave entitlements, and modify eligibility requirements. Proposals in the 114th Congress aimed to expand leave time and eligibility criteria. Currently, eligible employees can take 12 workweeks of FMLA leave for family and medical needs, and 26 workweeks to care for a seriously ill or injured servicemember. Some bills proposed additional leave entitlements for similar purposes. Two bills proposed additional entitlements for leave: Parental Involvement and Family Wellness Leave. H.R. 5518 would allow up to 24 hours of leave in a 12-month period for school conferences or medical care needs. H.R. 5535 would provide up to 48 hours of leave in a 12-month period for school-related activities. Employees can take up to 24 hours of leave in a 30-day period, with a maximum of 48 hours in a 12-month period, to attend school conferences or activities sponsored by a school or community organization for their child or grandchild. They must notify their employer at least seven days in advance. This is different from FMLA leave, which can be used for various reasons such as caring for a new child, a serious health condition, or a family member. Two bills proposed new eligibility requirements for certain veterans with service-connected disabilities and for education support professionals. H.R. 5518 aimed to reduce the minimum number of employees within 75 miles of an employee's worksite from 50 to 15, while H.R. 5496 proposed to amend the general hours-of-service requirement. It provided separate eligibility requirements for veterans with different disability ratings, allowing them to access FMLA-protected leave without meeting the standard employment requirements. Employees with a service-connected disability rated at 30% or higher can use FMLA leave for medical needs, with certification required. Veterans with a disability rated at 30%-50% can use leave after 8 months of employment, while those rated at 60% or higher can use leave after 6 months. S. 3444 would have allowed veterans with service-connected disabilities to access FMLA leave for medical needs sooner by reducing the employment and hours requirements. Veterans rated at 60% or higher could use leave after 6 months of employment and 625 hours, while those rated at 30% or higher would need certification from the Department of Defense for leave after 8 months and 833 hours.
